column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Riga/Outer East Bank
#Text=Outer East Bank is a part of Riga , here defined as the eastern bank of the Daugava river minus Old Riga and Centrs .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Getting in
#Text=by foot would mean a rather long walk as most points of interest are several kilometers from the more central parts of Riga .
#Text=Have a look at the network maps to see which tram , bus or trolleybus you need to take .
#Text=Driving can also be an option .
#Text=See
#Text=Grebenshchikov Church , Maza krasta iela 73 .
#Text=An Old Believers ' church .
#Text=Andrejsala .
#Text=An artists ' island is starting to emerge behind the passengers port a short distance north from the old town .
#Text=Riga Motor Museum , Eizensteina 6 ( 8km from the old town ; take trolleybus 14 or 18 to Gailezers Hospital , then walk 500m ) .
#Text=Contains former vehicles of Stalin , Kruschev , and Brezhnev .
#Text=Recently renovated .
#Text=€ 10 .

#Text=Riga Ethnographic Open Air Museum ( Latvijas Etnogrāfiskais Brīvdabas Muzejs ) , Brivibas 440 ( take the A2(E77 ) to the east out of Riga or take bus N.1 ) , ☏ +37167994106 , fax : +37167994178 , ✉ info@brivdabas-muzejs.lv .
#Text=The museum is in Jugla , near a lake of the same name .
#Text=There are many traditional Latvian countryside houses collected in a forest/park and exhibitions inside them about the traditional things .
#Text=The employees are often dressed in the traditional Latvian costumes , creating a nice atmosphere .
#Text=Grīziņkalns
#Text=St. Paul 's Church , Augusta Deglava iela 1 .
#Text=Neogothic church from 1885 marks the center of Riga 's main industrial neighborhood .
#Text=Most of the mural paintings are from 1930s and represent the art of independent Latvia before World War II .
#Text=Gas storage buildings .
#Text=Two gas storage buildings from 1882 and 1901 ( end of Matīsa iela ) are landmarks of the old gas factory in Riga .
#Text=These enormous structures reaching 40 m in diameter are probably the largest buildings of their kind in Eastern Europe .
#Text=Note the pressure meter that mimics a clock .
#Text=Baptist church , Matīsa iela 50b .
#Text=Light neo-Romanic building from 1867 looks completely alien to its dark industrial neighborhood .
#Text=Twin water towers .
#Text=Located at the crossing of three railway lines ( Mazā Matīsa iela ) , they are known among locals as Anna and Zhanna ( Ann and Joan ) .
#Text=Legend has it that Anna was a skilled quack in medieval Riga .
#Text=She was accused in being a witch and burnt to death .
#Text=This triggered her sister Zhanna to commit suicide .
#Text=Their ashes were brought to a place that was considered wicked , which is exactly the triangle between the railway lines where the water towers are located .
#Text=This place is indeed quite strange and renowned for its remoteness dominated by a huge cemetery and a prison .
#Text=The water towers from 1885-87 are very pretty , though , and seen from afar .
#Text=Matisa cemetery .
#Text=Matisa cemetery adjacent to the water towers has an interesting monument to the heroes of the Russian Revolution of 1905 .
#Text=The monument was built during the time of Soviet occupation ( 1956-59 ) and represents the typical gloomy-gray concrete style of Latvian military monuments constructed after World War II .
#Text=Another and equally gloomy 1905 monument is in the small park on Grīziņkalns hill on Pērnavas iela .
#Text=Russo-Balt factory .
#Text=Valmieras iela and adjacent streets boast gorgeous industrial buildings from late 19th century .
#Text=The largest factory was Russo-Balt that produced first cars and airplanes in the Russian empire .
#Text=Most of these buildings are now abandoned and derelict but quite interesting to see .
#Text=You will find lots of old plaques , signboards and other 100-year-old artifacts .
#Text=Southern and Eastern Maskavas forštate
#Text=The part of Maskavas forštate west of Lacplesa iela is covered in the Centrs article .
#Text=St. Francis Church , Katoļu iela 16 .
#Text=Built in 1892 , a gorgeous neo-Gothic building in the middle of slums .
#Text=Features copies of Giotto 's mural paintings in the Papal Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi .
#Text=All Saints Church , Katoļu iela 10 .
#Text=Orthodox church built in neo-Romanic style around 1880 .
#Text=Unlike other orthodox churches in Latvia , which are typically Russian in their style and nature , this one was designed by a Latvian architect .
#Text=Church of John the Baptist , Kalna iela 21 .
#Text=Construction started in 1913-14 but it was not finished before the Russian Revolution and continued in 1920s when Latvia became independent .
#Text=This led to a strange mix of styles rendering the church a rare example of modernist architecture implemented in an Orthodox temple .
#Text=The adjacent Ivanovskoe cemetery is the main Orthodox cemetery of Riga .
#Text=Church of Our Lady of Kazan , Kalna iela 21 .
#Text=Another church on the same cemetery .
#Text=Build of wood in 1812-15 in a somewhat awkward style with 5 small domes sitting on a massive drum .
#Text=Church of Gregory the Illuminator , Kojusalas iela 5 .
#Text=Armenian church built in 2011 .
#Text=Old New Synagogue ( Altnaie Schul ) , Maskavas iela 57 .
#Text=The only synagogue that survived through World War II .
#Text=Built in 1889 , partially restored after the war and converted into a residential building .
#Text=Church of Michael Archangel , Maskavas iela 170 .
#Text=Old Believers church from 1894-95 , nice example of the Russian Revival style .
#Text=Horse-drawn omnibus , Maskavas iela ( crossing with Mazā Kalna iela ) .
#Text=A funny monument commemorating the first Riga tram that was driven by horse power .
#Text=An old iron construction nearby reminds of the former Hay Market .
#Text=Old Jewish cemetery ( between Tējas iela and Ebreju iela ) .
#Text=A huge area that reminds of the Jewish population of Maskavas forštate .
#Text=Established in early 18th century , this cemetery kept expanding till the beginning of 20th century .
#Text=After all local Jews were exterminated by the Nazis during World War II , Soviet government destroyed the remaining gravestones and converted the area into a Park of Communist Brigades .
#Text=Now there is a small Jewish memorial .
#Text=Do
#Text=Mežaparks ( Take Tram 11 ) .
#Text=Forest Park is a pleasant park area on the outskirts of Riga .
#Text=There are large , gorgeous residential houses once inhabited by Riga 's prewar elite during the summers .
#Text=They were largely let go during Soviet times but many are now being refurbished , repainted , and brought back to their original glory .
#Text=Riga Zoo , Meza Prospekts 1 .
#Text=The Riga Zoo is small , but fairly popular .
#Text=Arena Riga , Skanstes iela 21 .
#Text=An indoor sports arena and concert venue .

#Text=Notable as the home rink of the city 's ice hockey team Dinamo Riga , playing in the KHL , the arena is also where the world 's greatest pop and rock artists and bands hold their Riga concerts .
